revisions.rev:
{{main|Occupy Wall Street}} {{Recentism|date=October 2011}} {{Use mdy dates|date=October 2011}} [[File:Day 12 Occupy Wall Street September 28 2011 Shankbone 33.JPG|thumb|Protester on September 28, 2011 (day 12): Zennie Abraham in the ''[[San Francisco Chronicle]]'' said on October 1 that the Occupy Wall Street protest "signals the start of a movement".<ref name=zennie>{{cite news|author =Abraham, Zennie|title=Occupy Wall Street Has Hot Chicks, Needs Plan|url=http://blog.sfgate.com/abraham/2011/10/01/occupy-wall-street-has-hot-chicks-needs-plan/|accessdate=October 16, 2011| publisher = ''City Brights Blog'' (blog hosted SFGate.com; site disclamer: "Editor's note: This is an SFGate.com ''City Brights Blog''. These blogs are not written or edited by SFGate or the ''[[San Francisco Chronicle]]''. The authors are solely responsible for the content.") |date=October 1, 2011}}</ref>]]
The following is a '''timeline of Occupy Wall Street''' (sometimes called '''OWS''' or '''#OWS''') which began on Saturday, September 17, 2011<ref>{{cite news| author = Moynihan, Colin |url=http://cityroom.blogs.nytimes.com/2011/09/17/wall-street-protest-begins-with-demonstrators-blocked/ |title=Wall Street Protest Begins, With Demonstrators Blocked |publisher= ''City Room'' (blog of ''[[The New York Times]]'' |date= September 17, 2011 |accessdate= October 16, 2011}}</ref> as an [[occupation (protest)|occupation]] of [[Wall Street]], the [[financial district]] of New York City and is an ongoing demonstration.<ref>{{Cite news |publisher= [[Bloomberg L.P.|Bloomberg]] | author = Marcinek, Laura |title =Protesters Converge on Lower Manhattan, Plan 'Occupation'|url=http://www.bloomberg.com/news/2011-09-16/wall-street-protesters-vow-to-occupy-lower-manhattan-for-months.html| date=September 17, 2011 | accessdate= October 16, 2011}}</ref>
OWS was preceded and partly inspired by the [[Arab Spring]] and [[2010â2011 Greek protests|Greek]], [[2011 Spanish protests|Spanish]], [[2011 United Kingdom anti-austerity protests|British]], [[2011 Chilean protests|Chilean]], and [[2011 Israeli middle class protests|Israeli]] protest movements. A precursor in the United States was the [[2011 Wisconsin protests]] occurring from late winter through the spring.
According to [http://15october.net/ 15october.net], as of October 15, 2011, the protests spread to more than 1,000 cities in 82 countries and formed a [["Occupy" protests|single global protest]].<ref>{{verify credibility|date=October 2011|reason=what are credentials of this website? no wikipedia article. a mainstream and third-party "reliable source"? to support?}}[http://15october.net/]. 15october.net.</ref>
==Chronology of events== ===Pre-September 17, 2011=== * '''June 9, 2011''' â a Canadian [[anti-consumerist]] magazine called ''[[Adbusters]]''{{clarify|date=October 2011|reason=was it the magazine "adbusters" or its publishing foundation "adbusters media foundation" who made the registration of domain name?}} registers the domain name occupywallstreet.org.<ref>{{cite web|title=WhoIs|url=http://www.whois.net/whois/occupywallstreet.org|accessdate=October 18, 2011}}</ref> * '''July 13 ''' â ''Adbusters'' makes the initial proposal for a peaceful demonstration to occupy Wall Street.<ref>{{cite web|author= Staff|url=http://www.adbusters.org/blogs/adbusters-blog/occupywallstreet.html |title=#OccupyWallStreet – A Shift in Revolutionary Tactics |publisher= ''Adbusters Blog'' (blog of [[Adbusters|Adbusters Media Foundation]]) |date=July 13, 2011 |accessdate= October 17, 2011}}</ref> * '''July 14 ''' â The domain name occupywallst.org is registered.{{clarify|date=October 2011|reason= prose for june 9 says "occupywallst.org" was registered then. two separate domain names or just confusion? if second (occupywallst.org) by whom?}} <ref>{{cite web|title=WhoIs|url=http://new.whois.net/whois/occupywallst.org|accessdate=November 1,2011}}</ref> * '''August 2''' â with the "debt-ceiling deadline" of midnight August 2 drawing near<ref>''I.e.'', the date and time when the U.S. would enter "sovereign default" status.</ref> ''(see: [[United States debt-ceiling crisis]])'', a group calling itself "New Yorkers Against Budget Cuts"<ref>{{cite web|author= Schneider, Nathan | date = September 29, 2011 | url=http://www.thenation.com/article/163719/occupy-wall-street-faq |title=Occupy Wall Street: FAQ | work = [[The Nation]] |date= |accessdate= October 19, 2011}}</ref> chose August 2 to incorporate a "General Assembly" with another group holding a strategy session for OWS. The two groups join in a demonstration at the [[Charging Bull]] sculpture, which stands in [[Bowling Green (New York City)|Bowling Green]] park in Lower Manhattan, at 4:30 p.m. Afterwards, these two groups "gather''[ed]'' into working groups to plan for the September 17 event".<ref>{{cite web|author = Staff | url=http://occupywallst.org/forum/august_2nd_wall_street_assembly/ |title=August 2nd General Assembly on Wall Street|publisher=Occupywallst.org |date=July 26, 2011 |accessdate= October 17, 2011}}</ref> * '''August 23''' â The [[hacktivism|hacktivist]] group [[Anonymous (group)|Anonymous]] encourages its followers to take part in the protest.<ref>{{cite web|author= Staff | date = August 23, 2011 |url=http://www.adbusters.org/blogs/adbusters-blog/anonymous-joins-occupywallstreet.html |title=Anonymous Joins #OccupyWallStreet – 'Wall Street, Expect Us!' Says Video Communique|publisher=''Adbusters Blog'' (blog of [[Adbusters|Adbusters Media Foundation]]) |accessdate= October 17, 2011}}</ref>
===September 2011=== [[File:Occupy Wall Street General Assembly 2011 Shankbone 4.jpg|thumb|September 3, 2011: A planning session for Occupy Wall Street is held at night in [[Tompkins Square Park]]]] [[File:Occupy Wall Street Day 2 crowd 2011 Shankbone.JPG|thumb|The crowd on September 18, 2011 (day 2).]] [[File:Day 14 Occupy Wall Street September 30 2011 Shankbone 51.JPG|thumb|Protesters demonstrate against [[police brutality]] outside NYPD headquarters on September 30, 2011 (day 14).]] * '''September 17 (day 1)''' â The first day of the OWS gathering. An estimated 1,000 people<ref>{{cite news| author = Zerbisias, Antonia |url=http://www.thestar.com/news/article/1057018 |title= Protests Dwindle in Attempt To 'Occupy Wall Street' |work= [[Toronto Star]] |date=September 20, 2011 |accessdate= October 17, 2011}}</ref> attend on the first day. Officers of the [[New York City Police Department]] (NYPD) prohibited protesters from erecting tents, citing [[loitering]] rules. Actress and comedienne [[Roseanne Barr]] speaks to protesters during the first day of the demonstration.<ref>Staff (September 19, 2011). [http://www.democracynow.org/2011/9/19/occupy_wall_street_thousands_march_in#.TndaZtA3RdY.twitter "'Occupy Wall Street': Thousands March in NYC Financial District, Set Up Protest Encampment"]. ''[[Democracy Now!]]''. Retrieved October 17, 2011.</ref> * '''September 19 (day 3)''' â The stock market opens on Wall Street for regular business. [[Keith Olbermann]], of [[Current TV]], becomes the first major journalist to focus on the protests. A couple days later, Olbermann criticizes mainstream media (MSM) for failing to cover Occupy Wall Street, saying, "Why isn't any major news outlet covering this? ... If that's a Tea Party protest in front of Wall Street ..., it's the lead story on every network newscast."<ref>{{cite web| author = Transcript | url=http://current.com/shows/countdown/videos/will-bunch-author-of-the-backlash-on-mainstream-medias-failure-to-cover-wall-street-protests |title=Will Bunch, Author of 'The Backlash,' on Mainstream Media's Failure To Cover Wall Street Protests |publisher= ''[[Countdown with Keith Olbermann]]'' (via [[Current TV]]) |date=September 21, 2011 |accessdate= October 18, 2011}}</ref> Olbermann now devotes every program to the protests, interviewing union leaders and members, eye-witnesses and protestors. Many other major news sources begin to publish articles on the occupation<ref>{{cite web| author = Database table | url=http://www.google.com/trends?q=occupy+wall+street |title= Occupy Wall Street |publisher= [[Google Trends]] |date=September 17, 2011 |accessdate= October 18, 2011}}</ref> and Occupy Wall Street caught some mainstream media attention across a wide variety of sources.<ref>{{cite web | author = Database | url=http://www.google.com/search?aq=f&hl=en&gl=us&tbm=nws&btnmeta_news_search=1&q=Occupy+Wall+Street#q=Occupy+Wall+Street&hl=en&safe=off&gl=us&sa=X&ei=iRZ5TpaDMYjfiALkovSsDw&ved=0CBgQpwUoCw&source=lnt&tbs=cdr:1%2Ccd_min%3A9%2F18%2F2011%2Ccd_max%3A9%2F21%2F2011&tbm=nws&bav=on.2,or.r_gc.r_pw.&fp=555b63af4e30e46b&biw=1268&bih=686 |title='Occupy Wall Street' – Sep 18, 2011âSep 21, 2011 | publisher = custom search of [[Google News]] aggregation | date=September 17, 2011| accessdate = October 18, 2011 }}</ref> * '''September 20 (day 4)''' â Police arrest mask-wearing protesters, using a law dating back to 1845 which bans masked gatherings unless part of "a masquerade party or like entertainment".<ref name="theweek1">{{cite web| author = Staff | url=http://theweek.com/article/index/220100/occupy-wall-street-a-protest-timeline |title= Occupy Wall Street: A Protest Timeline – A Relatively Small Gathering of Young Anarchists and Aging Hippies in Lower Manhattan Has Spawned a National Movement – What Happened? | work = [[The Week]] |date= October 11, 2011 |accessdate= October 18, 2011}}</ref> * '''September 22 (day 6)''' â Local media is reporting that a largely African American crowd of about 2,000 people march down from [[Union Square (New York City)|Union Square]], located at [[14th Street (Manhattan)|14th Street]] and [[Broadway (New York City)|Broadway]], to Wall Street to protest the execution of [[Troy Davis]]. Four people are arrested during the protests.<ref name="amsterdamnews1">{{cite news| author = Paye, Amity; Arinde, Nayaba |title=Protesters Stay in Liberty Square To Demonstrate Against Corporate Greed|url=http://www.amsterdamnews.com/news/local/article_133d2f3e-ea4d-11e0-88a1-001cc4c002e0.html|accessdate=October 18, 2011| work =[[New York Amsterdam News]]|date=September 29, 2011 }}</ref> * '''September 23 (day 7)''' â The action at Zuccotti Park, now renamed Liberty Square by the protesters, across the street from the [[One Liberty Plaza]] building in New York City continues.<ref name=olberman>{{verify credibility|date=October 2011|reason=what are credentials of "PlanetEarthAwakens01" (the YouTube poster)? does this attribution comply with [[WP:YOUTUBE]] including any copyright concerns? anyone can post stuff to youtube.}} {{cite web|author= Video (requires [[Adobe Flash]]; 00:07:11) |url=http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=s4QUePfHFQY&feature=related |title=Keith Olbermann Covers Occupy Wall Street Protests Media Blackout |publisher= PlanetEarthAwakens01 (via [[YouTube]]) |date=September 21, 2011 |accessdate= October 18, 2011}}</ref> ''[[The Colbert Report]]''<ref>{{cite web| author = Video (requires [[Adobe Flash]]; 00:03:06) | url=http://www.colbertnation.com/the-colbert-report-videos/397648/september-21-2011/wall-street-under-siege |title= Wall Street Under Siege | work= [[The Colbert Report]] |date=September 21, 2011 |accessdate= October 18, 2011}}</ref> satirizes the protests and major newspapers including ''[[The Guardian]]''<ref>{{cite news | author = Harris, Paul |url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/world/blog/2011/sep/21/occupy-wall-street-protests |title=Occupy Wall Street: The Protesters Speak – The Anti-Capitalist Protesters Who Have Set Up Camp in Lower Manhattan Are Becoming a Fixture of the Area | publisher = ''News Blog'' (blog of ''[[The Guardian]]'') |date=September 21, 2011 |accessdate= October 18, 2011 |location=London}}</ref> and ''[[The New York Times]]'' are reporting on the protests.<ref name=times>{{registration required|date=October 2011}} {{cite news| author = [[Ginia Bellafante|Bellafante, Ginia]]|title=Gunning for Wall Street, With Faulty Aim|url=http://www.nytimes.com/2011/09/25/nyregion/protesters-are-gunning-for-wall-street-with-faulty-aim.html|accessdate=September 24, 2011| work =[[The New York Times]]|date=September 23, 2011}}</ref> * '''September 24 (day 8)''' â At least 80 arrests are made by the NYPD<ref name=arrests>{{cite web|author = Staff | date = September 24, 2011 | title=Occupy Wall Street Movement Reports 80 Arrested Today in Protests|url=http://abcnews.go.com/blogs/headlines/2011/09/occupy-wall-street-movement-reports-80-arrested-today-in-protests/|publisher= ''Nation'' (blog of [[ABC News]]) | accessdate= October 18, 2011}}</ref> after protesters begin marching uptown, forcing the closure of several streets.<ref>{{cite news| author = Staff | date = September 24, 2011 | title=Police Arrest 80 During 'Occupy Wall Street' Protest|url=http://www.foxnews.com/us/2011/09/24/police-arrest-80-during-occupy-wall-street-protest/|publisher= [[Associated Press]] (via [[Fox News]]) |accessdate= October 18, 2011}}</ref> Soon after the arrests, videos begin to appear around the web. In particular, public concern is raised by a video released later in the day showing young women being maced by a police officer.<ref>{{verify credibility|date=October 2011|reason=what are credentials of "TheOther99Percent" (the YouTube poster)? anyone can post stuff taken anywhere to youtube.}} {{cite web|author= Video (requires [[Adobe Flash]]; 00:00:40) |url=http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=moD2JnGTToA |title=Peaceful Female Protestors Penned in the Street and Maced! – #Occupywallstreet |publisher= TheOther99Percent (via [[YouTube]]) |date=September 24, 2011 |accessdate= October 19, 2011}}</ref> * '''September 25 (day 9)''' â YouTube discloses that the hacktivist group ''Anonymous'' uploads a video around 4:30 pm on this day, threatening the NYPD: "If we hear of brutality in the next 36 hours then we will take you down from the internet as you have taken the protesters[sic] voices from the airwaves."<ref>{{cite web| author = Mathias, Christopher | url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2011/09/27/anonymous-threatens-nypd-_n_983941.html |title=Anonymous Threatens NYPD After Alleged Police Brutality During #OccupyWallStreet Protests (Video) |publisher = ''Christopher Mathias Blog'' (blog of ''[[The Huffington Post]]'') |date=September 27, 2011 |accessdate= October 19, 2011}}</ref> * '''September 26 (day 10)''' â The name of the police officer who maced some young women on September 24 is revealed as '''Anthony Bologna'''. The official OWS website claims that this incident occurred without provocation, demanding jail time for Bologna and the resignation of [[New York City Police Commissioner|NYC Police Commissioner]] [[Raymond Kelly]].<ref>{{cite web| author = Staff | url=https://occupywallst.org/article/Officer-Bologna/ |title=Officer Bologna |publisher= [[OccupyWallSt.org]] |date= September 26, 2011 |accessdate= October 19, 2011}}</ref><ref name="Bologna New York Magazine story">{{cite news| author = Coscarelli, Joe|title=Anonymous Outs NYPD Officer Who Pepper-Sprayed OWS Protesters |url=http://nymag.com/daily/intel/2011/09/anonymous_outs_nypd_officer_wh.html| publisher = ''Daily Intel'' (blog of ''[[New York (magazine)|New York]]'')|date=September 26, 2011 | accessdate = October 19, 2011}}</ref> [[Noam Chomsky]] sends a public "strong message of support" to the organizers of the OWS protests.<ref>{{cite web| author = Metzger, Richard |url=http://www.dangerousminds.net/comments/noam_chomsky_on_the_wall_street_protests/ |title=Noam Chomsky on the Wall Street Protests |publisher=Dangerous Minds |accessdate= October 1, 2011}}</ref> In the evening hours, filmmaker [[Michael Moore]] addresses the crowd at Zuccotti Park.<ref>{{cite web| author = Strachan, Jessica|title=Michael Moore Gives Speech at Liberty Plaza for 'Occupy Wall Street'|url=http://www.mlive.com/entertainment/flint/index.ssf/2011/09/michael_moore_gives_speech_at.html|work= [[Flint Journal]] |accessdate=September 27, 2011}}</ref> * '''September 27 (day 11)''' â An OWS afternoon march ends not at Wall Street but at a rally by postal workers protesting against a five-day delivery week. OWS lends their support to this rally, supporting the belief that this cutback to the delivery week severely harms the postal service and will cause significant job losses.<ref>{{cite web| author = Webster, Stephen C. |url=http://www.rawstory.com/rawreplay/2011/09/occupy-wall-st-joins-postal-workers-in-budget-protest/ |title='Occupy Wall St.' Joins Postal Workers in Budget Protest | Raw Replay |publisher=Rawstory.com |date=September 27, 2011 |accessdate= October 1, 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=Artists |first=Philosopher |url=http://davidscameracraft.blogspot.com/2011/09/occupy-wall-street-media-delay.html |title=Occupy Wall Street Media delay | Davids Camera Craft |publisher=Davidscameracraft.blogspot.com |accessdate= September 29, 2011}}</ref> [[New York City Council|NYC Councilman]] [[Charles Barron]] visits Zuccotti Park addressing those gathered with public support for OWS.<ref name="amsterdamnews1"/> Later, Dr. [[Cornel West]] speaks to the gathering at the park and opens the daily General Assembly (now meeting at 7 pm each evening).<ref>{{cite web|author=Robbins, Christopher |url=http://gothamist.com/2011/09/27/dr_cornel_west_joins_occupy_wall_st.php#photo-1 |title=Dr. Cornel West Joins Occupy Wall Street, Will Lead Meeting Tonight |publisher= [[Gothamist]] |accessdate= September 29, 2011}}</ref> Later it is reported by the official Occupy Wall Street website that "nearly two thousand people gathered to hear Dr. West speak."<ref>{{cite web|url=https://occupywallst.org/article/day-eleven/ |title=A Message From Occupied Wall Street (Day Eleven) |publisher=OccupyWallSt.org |accessdate= September 29, 2011}}</ref> * '''September 28 (day 12)''' â According to various sources,<ref>{{dead link|date=October 2011|reason=continual redirect to redirect to redirect, ad nasaeum. perhaps temporary; tried mutliple times over twelve-hour period.}} [http://www.crainsnewyork.com/article/20110929/FINANCE/110929865]. ''[[Crain's New York Business]]''.</ref><ref>{{cite news|last=Lopez|first=Linette|title=A Massive Union Just Voted To Side With The Wall Street Protesters|url=http://www.businessinsider.com/a-massive-union-just-voted-to-side-with-the-wall-street-protesters-2011-9|accessdate=October 5, 2011| work =[[Business Insider]]|date=September 29, 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=NYC Transit Union Joins Occupy Wall Street|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2011/09/29/nyc-transit-union-joins-o_n_987156.html|accessdate=October 5, 2011|work= [[The Huffington Post]] |date=September 29, 2011}}</ref> the board of the local union of the [[Transport Workers Union of America]] (TWU Local-100) votes to support Occupy Wall Street.<ref>{{cite web|last=Doll, Jen |url=http://blogs.villagevoice.com/runninscared/2011/09/transport_worke.php |title= Occupy Wall Street – Transport Workers Union Votes Unanimously To Support Occupy Wall Street |publisher= ''Runnin' Scared'' (blog of ''[[The Village Voice]]'') |date=September 25, 2011 |accessdate= October 16, 2011}}</ref> Police Commissioner Kelly publicly states that the NYPD cannot bar protesters from Zuccotti Park since it is a privately owned public park and plaza that is required to stay open 24 hours a day.<ref name="Fractenberg">Fractenberg, Ben (September 28, 2011). [http://www.dnainfo.com/20110928/downtown/zuccotti-park-cant-be-closed-wall-street-protesters-nypd-says "Zuccotti Park Can't Be Closed to Wall Street Protesters, NYPD Says"] ''DNA Info''. Retrieved October 7, 2011.</ref> * '''September 29 (day 13)''' â Pulitzer prize-winning reporter [[Chris Hedges]] publishes a column in strong support of OWS.<ref>"There are no excuses left. Either you join the revolt taking place on Wall Street and in the financial districts of other cities across the country or you stand on the wrong side of history."</ref><ref>{{cite web| author = [[Chris Hedges|Hedges, Chris]] | url=http://www.truthdig.com/report/item/the_best_among_us_20110929/ |title=The Best Among Us |publisher= [[Truthdig]] |date= September 29, 2011 |accessdate= October 20, 2011}}</ref> TWU Local-100 uses Twitter to urge members to take part in a "massive march and rally" on October 5.<ref name="talkingpointsmemo1">{{cite web|author = Franzen, Carl | date = September 29, 2011 |url=http://idealab.talkingpointsmemo.com/2011/09/occupy-wall-street-protests-poised-to-grow-rapidly-with-union-support.php?ref=fpa |title=Occupy Wall Street Protests Poised To Grow Rapidly With Union Support |publisher= ''Idea Lab'' (blog of [[Talking Points Memo]]) |accessdate= October 20, 2011}}</ref> There are unsubstantiated claims that the October 5 event is now co-sponsored by another eight labor and community outreach organizations.<ref name="talkingpointsmemo1"/> Meanwhile, protesters in San Francisco attempt to occupy Citibank, Chase, and attempted to enter a [[Charles Schwab]] financial institution, with some media outlets citing OWS as the inspiration for the spread of such protests which are occurring more frequently around the nation.<ref>{{clarify|date=October 2011|reason=attiribution is in slovenian language. at minimum, needs english translation of slovenian headline appended to "trans_title" field.}} {{cite web| author = Staff | date = September 30, 2011 | url=http://24ur.com/novice/svet/okupacija-wall-streeta-po-new-yorku-se-san-francisco.html#comment |title=Okupacija Wall Streeta: Po New Yorku Å¡e San Francisco | trans_title = | language = [[Slovenian language|Slovenia]] | publisher= [[24ur.com]] |accessdate= October 20, 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite web| author = Bowe, Rebecca | date = August 29, 2011 | url=http://sfbayguardian.com/politics/2011/09/29/breaking-six-arrested-protesting-bank-foreclosures |title=Six Arrested Protesting Bank Foreclosures During Occupy SF | publisher = ''Politics'' (blog of the ''[[San Francisco Bay Guardian]]'') |accessdate= October 20, 2011}}</ref> * '''September 30 (day 14)''' â More than 1,000 demonstrators, including representatives from various labor organizations, are holding a peaceful march to the [[1 Police Plaza|NYPD headquarters]], a few blocks north of nearby [[New York City Hall]], to protest what they said was a heavy-handed police response the previous week. No arrests are reported.<ref>{{cite news| author = Sanchez, Ray|title= More Than 50 Arrested in Wall Street Protest|url=http://news.yahoo.com/wall-street-protesters-march-police-025924383.html| publisher = [[Reuters]] (via [[Yahoo! News]]) |date=October 1, 2011 | accessdate = October 20, 2011}}</ref>
===October 2011=== [[File:Day 17 Occupy Wall Street October 3 2011 Shankbone.JPG|thumb|Protesters marching as corporate zombies on October 3]] * '''October 1 (day 15)''' â More than 5,000 people march towards the [[Brooklyn Bridge]], while hundreds march onto its pedestrian area and car lanes, taking over part of the bridge. Traffic into Brooklyn is stopped by the police for roughly two hours. Police split the crowd into two sections, enclosing a few hundred that were on the bridge between two lines of netting and [[kettling]] them â slowly closing in and keeping them from moving about. Over 700 arrests are being made, while police call for paddy wagons and buses to transport the arrested, including a ''New York Times'' reporter who was on the bridge. Some others caught on the bridge are allowed to walk away. The remaining protesters gather that evening in Zuccotti Park.<ref>{{cite news | author = Staff | title = 700 Arrested After Wall Street Protest on Brooklyn Bridge | url = http://www.foxnews.com/us/2011/10/01/500-arrested-after-wall-street-protest-on-nys-brooklyn-bridge/?test=latestnews | date = October 1, 2011 | accessdate = October 20, 2011 |publisher= [[Fox News]]}}</ref>
* '''October 2 (day 16)''' â Videos went "viral" showing the police first preventing and then permitting some of the protesters to walk onto the bridge's main road where they were then arrested on traffic disruption charges:<ref>{{verify credibility|date=October 2011|reason=what are credential of youtube poster "headgirl"? anyone can post anything to youtube.}} {{cite web| author = Video (requires [[Adobe Flash]]; 00:04:27) | date = October 2, 2011 (posted) | url=http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Yxe0dojwBJQ|title=Brooklyn Bridge Protesters Illegally Ketteled Video Proof / 700 Illegal Arrests|publisher= HeadGirl (via [[YouTube]])| accessdate = October 20, 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.roarmag.org/2011/10/how-the-new-york-times-manipulated-blame-for-mass-arrests/|title=How ''The New York Times'' Manipulated Blame for Arrests| author = Ross, JÃ©rome E.|date=October 2, 2011|publisher=Roarmag.org | accessdate = October 20, 2011}}</ref>
* '''October 3 (day 17)''' â Hundreds of protesters in New York City dress as "corporate zombies" and [[zombie walk]] past Wall Street with painted faces, carrying fake dollar bills.<ref>{{dead link|date=October 2011}} {{cite news|title=Anti-Wall Street Protests Spread Nationwide|url=http://www.cbsnews.com/stories/2011/10/03/ap/business/main20114915.shtml|accessdate=October 3, 2011|publisher =[[CBS News]]|date=October 3, 2011|deadurl=yes}}</ref>
* '''October 5 (day 19)''' â Joined by union members, students, and the unemployed, the demonstrations swelled to the largest yet with an estimated 5,000 to 15,000 demonstrators marching from lower Manhattan's [[Foley Square]] to Zuccotti Park. The march is mostly peaceful&nbsp until after nightfall when scuffles erupt and some of the younger demonstrators are arrested after they storm barricades blocking them from Wall Street. About 200 people tried to push through barricades and police respond with pepper spray and "kettle" them in with orange netting.<ref>{{cite news| author = Boyle, Christina; Sher, Emily; Mullany, Anjali; Kennedy, Helen|title=Occupy Wall Street Protests: Police Make Arrests, Use Pepper Spray as Some Activists Storm Barricade|url=http://www.nydailynews.com/ny_local/2011/10/05/2011-10-05_occupy_wall_street_protests_unions_join_epic_march_in_downtown_manhattan.html|accessdate=October 20, 2011| work =[[Daily News (New York)|Daily News]]|date=October 5, 2011}}</ref> Smaller protests continue in cities and on college campuses across the country.<ref>{{cite news| author = Staff | date = October 5, 2011 | url=http://www.reuters.com/article/2011/10/06/wallstreet-protests-idUSN1E79424220111006 |title=Update 4 – Wall Street Protest Grows as Unions Swell Ranks |publisher= [[Reuters]] |accessdate= October 20, 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite news| author = Wells, Matt; McVeigh, Karen |title=Occupy Wall Street: Thousands March in New York – Thousands Gathering in Fine Autumn Sunshine as Big US Unions Back the Occupy Wall Street Protests |url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/world/2011/oct/05/occupy-wall-street-new-york-march?newsfeed=true|accessdate=October 20, 2011| work = [[The Guardian]]|date=October 5, 2011 |location=London}}</ref>
* '''October 6 (day 20)''' â About 5,000 protesters march in [[Portland, Oregon|Portland]], [[Oregon]].<ref>{{cite news| author = Staff | title=Occupy Portland: March Leads to Protest at Pioneer Courthouse Square and Back onto Downtown Streets|url=http://www.oregonlive.com/portland/index.ssf/2011/10/occupy_portland_march_leads_to.html|accessdate=October 20, 2011| work = [[The Oregonian]] |date=October 6, 2011}}</ref> More demonstrations were held in [[Los Angeles]] and [[San Francisco]], [[California]]; [[Tampa, Florida|Tampa]], [[Florida]]; [[Occupy Houston|Houston]], [[Austin, Texas|Austin]], [[Texas]], and [[Salt Lake City]]. Asked about OWS, [[President of the United States|U.S. President]] [[Barak Obama]] replied: "I think it expresses the frustrations the American people feel, that we had the biggest financial crisis since the Great Depression, huge collateral damage all throughout the country... and yet you're still seeing some of the same folks who acted irresponsibly trying to fight efforts to crack down on the abusive practices that got us into this in the first place."<ref name="theweek1"/>
* '''October 8 (day 22)''' – Protesters were pepper sprayed in Washington, D.C., as they attempted to enter the [[National Air and Space Museum]] and one protester pushed a security guard against the wall. The group of "100 to 200" protesters intended to target displays about [[Unmanned combat air vehicle|military drones]]; one was arrested.<ref>{{cite news| author = Zuckerman, Alex|title=Pepper Spray Used on Demonstrators at Air and Space Museum|url=http://www.cnn.com/2011/10/08/politics/dc-protest-museum/index.html?hpt=hp_t1|accessdate=October 20, 2011 | publisher = [[CNN]] |date=October 9, 2011}}</ref> One thousand protesters marched from Zuccotti Park to [[Washington Square Park]], located in Manhattan's [[Greenwich Village]], without incident amid speculation that the protests would relocate there.<ref>{{cite news| author = Baker, Al|title=Wall Street Protest Visits Washington Sq.|url=http://cityroom.blogs.nytimes.com/2011/10/08/wall-street-protest-moves-to-washington-sq/|accessdate=October 20, 2011| publisher = ''City Room'' (blog of ''[[The New York Times]]'') |date=October 8, 2011}}</ref>
[[File:Day 28 Occupy Wall Street Tom Morello 2011 Shankbone 5.JPG|thumb|The crowd listening to [[Tom Morello]] of [[Rage Against the Machine]] on October 13, 2011]] * '''October 9 (day 23)''' – A crowd of approximately 100 protesters gathered in Washington, D.C., outside the [[White House]].<ref>{{cite news| author = Staff | date = October 9, 2011 | title=Arrest Outside White House as Lawmakers Debate Protests|url=http://www.cnn.com/2011/10/09/us/occupy-wall-street/ | publisher = [[CNN]] |accessdate=October 20, 2011}}</ref> ''[[The American Spectator]]'', a conservative monthly magazine, posted an article by assistant editor Patrick Howley in which he revealed he had infiltrated the group of protesters who had attempted to enter the National Air and Space Museum on October 8. Howley claimed to have helped instigate the events that prompted the museum to close in order to discredit the protest movement. Commenting on the incident, an activist at Occupy Wall Street said that there were "obvious provocateurs" in the movement, and that a committee had been set up to identify and warn others about them.<ref>{{cite news| author = Khimm, Suzy | date = October 9, 2011 | url=http://www.washingtonpost.com/blogs/ezra-klein/post/conservative-journalist-says-he-infiltrated-escalated-dc-museum-protest/2011/10/09/gIQAIKxCYL_blog.html |title=Conservative Journalist Says He Infiltrated, Escalated D.C. Museum Protest | publisher = ''[[Ezra Klein|Ezra Klein's Wonkblog]]'' (via ''[[The Washington Post]]'') |accessdate= October 20, 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|author=McVeigh, Karen |url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/world/2011/oct/10/washington-protest-american-spectator-patrick-howley?newsfeed=true |title=Washington Protest: American Spectator Condemned over Article | work = [[The Guardian]] |date= October 10, 2011|accessdate= October 13, 2011 |location=London}}</ref> Meanwhile, at Zuccotti Park, [[Slovenes|Slovenian]] [[philosopher]] [[Slavoj Å½iÅ¾ek]] addressed the crowd and expressed support for the protests<ref>{{clarify|date=October 2011|reason=attribution in slovenian language. at minimum, needs english translation of headline appended in "trans_title" field.}} {{cite web|url=http://24ur.com/novice/svet/zakona-med-kapitalizmom-in-demokracijo-je-konec.html |title=Å½iÅ¾ek: Protestniki nismo komunisti | trans_title = | language = [[Slovenian language|Slovenian]] | publisher=24ur.com |date= |accessdate= October 13, 2011}}</ref> during one of several "open forums" conducted throughout the day around Zuccotti Park.
* '''October 10 (day 24)''' – [[Mayor of New York City|NYC Mayor]] [[Michael Bloomberg]] suggested that he did not anticipate an effort by the city to remove the demonstrators. "The bottom line is, people want to express themselves, and as long as they obey the laws, we'll allow them to," the mayor told reporters at the start of the city's 67th annual [[Columbus Day]] parade. The official @OccupyWallSt Twitter account declares, "Bloomberg said we can stay indefinitely! Big win!"<ref>{{cite news|author=Taylor, Kate; Kaplan, Thomas|title=Bloomberg Says Protesters Can Stay On, if They Obey Laws |url=http://cityroom.blogs.nytimes.com/2011/10/10/bloomberg-says-protesters-can-stay-on-if-they-obey-laws/|accessdate=October 11, 2011| publisher = ''City Room'' (blog of ''[[The New York Times]]'') |date=October 10, 2011}}</ref> Police reported that more than 140 protesters from the [[Occupy Boston]] movement were arrested after they ignored warnings to move from a downtown greenway near where they have been camped out for more than a week.<ref>{{cite news| author = Staff | date = October 11, 2011 | url=http://www.usatoday.com/news/nation/story/2011-10-11/boston-protesters-arrested/50727182/1 |title=Boston Police Arrest 50 Occupy Boston Protesters | publisher = [[Associated Press]] (via ''[[USA Today]]'') |accessdate= October 20, 2011}}</ref>
* '''October 13 (day 27)''' – Mayor Bloomberg told demonstrators they would need to clear Zuccotti Park for it to be cleaned. In response organizers issued a call for cleaning supplies and say they intend to clean the space themselves.<ref>Staff (October 13, 2011). [http://www.democracynow.org/2011/10/13/headlines#1 "Headlines for October 13, 2011"]. ''[[Democracy Now!]]''. Retrieved October 16, 2011.</ref> The NYPD issued a statement saying that the protesters would no longer be allowed to keep sleeping equipment in the area.<ref> Gabbatt, Adam (October 13, 2011).[http://www.guardian.co.uk/world/blog/2011/oct/13/occupy-wall-street-protests-eviction-live#block-13 "Occupy Wall Street: Protesters Fear Eviction – Thursday 13 October 2011 – Occupy Wall Street Protesters Are Bracing Themselves for Eviction as Police Insist They Will Not Be Allowed To Keep Sleeping Equipment in Zuccotti Park After It Is Cleaned"]. ''News Blog'' (blog of ''[[The Guardian]]''). Retrieved October 16, 2011.</ref> [[Reuters]] published an article in which they claimed to have found indirect financial links between [[George Soros]] and Adbusters, the group which initiated the OWS protests.<ref>Egan, Mark; Nichols, Michelle (October 13, 2011). [http://www.reuters.com/article/2011/10/14/us-wallstreet-protests-origins-idUSTRE79C1YN20111014 "Who's Behind the Wall Street Protests?"]. [[Reuters]]. Retrieved October 16, 2011.</ref>
* '''October 14 (day 28)''' – [[Brookfield Office Properties]] postponed cleaning its Zuccotti Park.<ref>Deprez, EsmÃ© E.; Stonington, Joel; Dolmetsch, Chris (October 14, 2011). [http://www.bloomberg.com/news/2011-10-14/occupy-wall-street-park-cleaning-is-postponed-as-14-protesters-in-custody.html "Occupy Wall Street Park Cleaning Postponed"]. [[Bloomberg L.P.|Bloomberg]]. Retrieved October 16, 2011.</ref> [[Reuters]] published an article in which they refuted an earlier claim to have found indirect financial links between [[George Soros]] and Adbusters, the group which initiated the OWS protests.<ref>Egan, Mark; Nichols, Michelle (October 13, 2011). [http://www.reuters.com/article/2011/10/14/us-wallstreet-protests-funding-idUSTRE79D01Q20111014 "Soros: Not a Funder of Wall Street Protests"]. [[Reuters]]. Retrieved October 15, 2011.</ref>
<!-- Deleted image removed: [[File:Caitlin sign.jpg|thumb|right|Caitlin Curran holding a sign with a quote from [[Conor Friedersdorf]] at Occupy Wall Street demonstration held at Times Square New York on October 15, 2011. She was fired from her job as a journalist on October 17 since she was covering the event and "made the decision to participate in the protest and make herself part of the story, [in which] she violated [WNYC's] editorial standards".<ref>[http://www.theatlanticwire.com/national/2011/10/another-public-radio-freelancer-gets-ax-over-occupy-wall-street/44278/ Adam Clark Estes and Dino Grandoni, âAnother Public Radio Freelancer Gets the Ax Over Occupy Wall Streetâ, The Atlantic, October 28, 2011]</ref> Photo by Ben Furnas.]] --> * '''October 15 (day 29)''' – Thousands of protesters marched through Manhattan to [[Times Square]] where they faced its [[United States Armed Forces|U.S. Armed Forces]] recruiting station to protest the money being spent on foreign wars instead of on people in the U.S. struggling with no jobs and no health care. Sparked by the OWS movement, dozens of protests were held in the U.S. and around the world. Most of the protests were peaceful,<ref>Schabner, Dean; Gray, Katti; [[Dan Kloeffler|Kloeffler, Dan]] (October 15, 2011). [http://abcnews.go.com/Business/occupy-wall-street-movement-worldwide/story?id=14743648 "Occupy Wall Street Marchers Take Times Square"]. [[ABC News]]. Retrieved October 16, 2011.</ref> however many people were arrested across the U.S., largely for refusing to vacate public property. [[Cornel West]] was arrested on the steps of the Supreme Court in Washington D.C. protesting corporate influence in politics. In Rome, the protests turned violent after rioters hijacked a peaceful gathering causing an estimated $1.4 million of damage.<ref>{{cite news|author= Longbottom, Wil | date = October 18, 2011 | url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-2049985/Martin-Luther-King-Jr-Memorial-dedication-Obama-offers-support-Occupy-protesters.html |title= Obama's Backing for Greed Protesters: 'MLK Would Want Us To Challenge Excesses of Wall Street' – U.S. President Calls on Protesters Not To 'Demonise' Wall Street Workers – Hundreds Arrested Across America After Weekend of Demonstrations – $1.4M of Damage Caused in Violent Clashes in Rome – Republican Eric Cantor Cedes There Is 'Too Much' Income Disparity in the U.S. | work = [[Daily Mail]] |accessdate = October 20, 2011 | location=London}}</ref>
* '''October 16 (day 30)''' – President Obama extended support for the protesters.<ref>{{registration required|date=October 2011}} {{cite web| author = Bond, Shannon | url=http://www.ft.com/intl/cms/s/0/052226f8-f80c-11e0-a419-00144feab49a.html#axzz1b0npYW63 |title=Obama Extends Support for Protesters | work = [[Financial Times]] |date=October 16, 2011 |accessdate=October 17, 2011}}</ref> and the [[White House]] issued a statement saying Obama is working for the interests of the 99%.<ref>{{cite web| author = Miller, Zeke | url=http://www.businessinsider.com/white-house-draws-closer-to-occupy-wall-street-says-obama-is-fighting-for-interests-of-the-99-2011-10| title= White House Draws Closer To Occupy Wall Street, Says Obama Is Fighting for the Interests of the 99% |publisher=[[Business Insider]] |date=October 16, 2011 |accessdate=October 17, 2011}}</ref> The [[New York City General Assembly]] Demands Working Group produced a call for a [["Occupy" protests#Call for a constitutional convention|constitutional amendment]] and national convention to be held July 4, 2012, in [[Philadelphia, Pennsylvania|Philadelphia]].<ref name=kingkade>Kingkade, Tyler (October 18, 2011). [http://www.huffingtonpost.com/mobileweb/2011/10/18/occupy-wall-street-planning-convention_n_1018570.html "Occupy Wall Street Protesters Propose A National Convention, Release Potential Demands"]. ''[[The Huffington Post]]''. Retrieved October 20, 2011.</ref><ref name=99percentdeclaration>New York City General Assembly Demands Working Group (October 16, 2011). [https://sites.google.com/site/the99percentdeclaration/ The 99 Percent Declaration]. Retrieved October 20, 2011.</ref> However, it is not representative of OWS or the NYC General Assembly.<ref name=kingkade/> It is a draft document and will remain as such until issues are resolved regarding the status of the Working Group.<ref name=kingkade/>
*'''October 17 (day 31)''' – Freelance journalist, Caitlin Curran, is fired from public radio station [[WNYC]] for holding a protest sign and the Occupy Wall Street event at Times Square NYC on October 15. She was covering the event at the time. Her manager fired her for violating editorial standards by participating in a protest she was covering.<ref>[http://www.theatlanticwire.com/national/2011/10/another-public-radio-freelancer-gets-ax-over-occupy-wall-street/44278/ Adam Clark Estes and Dino Grandoni, âAnother Public Radio Freelancer Gets the Ax Over Occupy Wall Streetâ, The Atlantic, October 28, 2011]</ref>
*'''October 20 (day 34)''' – Freelance journalist, [[Lisa Simeone]] is fired from her position as a host of Soundprint, a journalistic program produced for [[National Public Radio]] (NPR), for her leadership role in [[October 2011]], an [[Occupy D.C.]] organization. Both Soundprint and NPR considered her role to be a violation of journalistic standards.<ref>[http://soundprint.org/ |Soundprint annoucement re Lisa Simeone firing]</ref><ref>[http://www.baltimoresun.com/entertainment/tv/z-on-tv-blog/bal-npr-lisa-simeone-fired-soundprint-occupy-dc-20111020,0,939396.story David Zurawik âLisa Simeone confirms her firing from public radio's 'Soundprint' showâ, Baltimore Sun, October 21, 2011]</ref>
* '''October 25 (day 39)''' – [[2011 Egyptian revolution|Egyptian activists]] who helped topple former dictator [[Hosni Mubarak]] lent their support to the growing Occupy movement, releasing a statement in solidarity with occupiers.<ref>{{cite news| author = Jack Shenker and Adam Gabbatt| url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/world/2011/oct/25/egyptian-protesters-occupy-wall-street|title=Tahrir Square protesters send message of solidarity to Occupy Wall Street| work = [[The Guardian]] |date=October 25, 2011 |accessdate=October 26, 2011| location=London}}</ref><ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/commentisfree/2011/oct/25/occupy-movement-tahrir-square-cairo|title=To the Occupy movement â the occupiers of Tahrir Square are with you| work = [[The Guardian]] |date=October 25, 2011 |accessdate=October 26, 2011|location=London}}</ref> In [[Oakland]], [[California]], hundreds of police move against [[Occupy Oakland]] protesters, launching [[teargas]], [[beanbag round]]s, and rubber bullets before clearing out an encampment and arresting 85 people. A protest march later in the day resulted in additional use of teargas and [[rubber bullet|rubber bullets]]. An [[Iraq War]] veteran from the [[United States Marine Corps|U.S. Marines]] is in critical condition after "being hit in the head by a police projectile." <ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/world/blog/2011/oct/26/occupy-oakland-protests-live|title=Occupy Oakland protests - live coverage| work = [[The Guardian]] |date=October 26, 2011 |accessdate=October 26, 2011|location=London|first=Adam|last=Gabbatt}}</ref>
* '''October 26 (day 40)''' – Hundreds of OWS protesters marched near Union Square in support of [[Iraq War]] veteran and [[Occupy Oakland]] protester Scott Olsen who is in intensive care as a result of a police-fired projectile during the October 25 [[Occupy Oakland]] march. <ref>{{cite news|title=Occupy Wall Street protesters support injured war vet|url=http://www.cnn.com/2011/10/27/us/occupy-wall-street/|accessdate=27 October 2011|newspaper=CNN|date=26 October 2011}}</ref>
* '''October 27 (day 41)''' – Jean Quan, mayor of Oakland, said the Occupy Oakland protesters could stay, in the wake of Tuesday's violent police eviction of the encampment in front of City Hall.<ref>{{cite news|title=Quan Pulls 180, Allows Occupy Oakland to Stay|url=http://www.nbcbayarea.com/news/local/Quan-Pulls-180-Allows-Occupy-Oakland-to-Stay-132726453.html|author=Chris Roberts|accessdate=28 October 2011|newspaper=NBC Bay Area|date=27 October 2011}}</ref>
* '''October 29 (day 43)''' – Tensions flared in [[Denver]], [[Colorado]] near the [[Colorado State Capitol|State Capitol]] when police entered the campsite. There were reports of skirmishes between police and protesters, with more than a dozen arrests. A group of protesters characterized as "thugs" surrounded and pushed over a police motorcycle while the policeman was riding it. The police dispersed the OWS protesters by firing rounds of pellets filled with pepper spray.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://apnews.myway.com/article/20111030/D9QMCJLO0.html|title=Occupy Denver tension escalates dramatically|date=Oct 29, 2011|author=Kristen Wyatt|accessdate=Oct. 30, 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://tv.breitbart.com/occupydenver-thugs-knock-motorcycle-cop-to-ground/|title=#OccupyDenver Thugs Knock Motorcycle Cop To Ground|date=October 30, 2011|author=Citizen Journalist|accessdate=Oct.30, 2011}}</ref> [[File:OWS literature.jpg|thumb|right|A late October edition of ''The Occupied Wall Street Journal'', along with pamphlets on anarchism and the NYC General Assembly]]
*'''October 30 (day 44)''' – Police arrested two dozen people in Portland, Oregon, for failing to leave a park when it closed at midnight. Police arrested 38 people in Austin, Texas after they refused to put away food tables at 10 pm. The arrested people contested the legitimacy of the Austin rule since it was issued by City Hall two days earlier and not passed by a City Council vote.<ref> {{cite news| url=http://www.cnn.com/2011/10/30/us/texas-occupy-austin/?hpt=ju_c2 | work=CNN | title=Dozens of Occupy protesters arrested in Texas, Oregon - CNN.com | date=October 31, 2011}}</ref>
=== November 2011 ===
* '''November 2 (day 47)''' – Demonstrations continued in [[Occupy Oakland|Oakland]], California, with a citywide general strike taking place in response to the serious injury sustained by a protester on October 25.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://edition.cnn.com/2011/11/02/us/occupy-demonstrators/index.html?iref=allsearch|publisher=CNN|title=Demonstrators gear up for Oakland strike as protests continue|date=November 2, 2011|accessdate=November 2, 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-us-canada-15481506|title=Occupy Oakland seeks strike after Scott Olsen injury|publisher=BBC|date=27 October 2011|accessdate=November 2, 2011}}</ref> Protesters shut down the [[Port of Oakland]], the nation's fifth busiest port.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nbcbayarea.com/news/local/Occupy-Oakland-Hosts-General-Strike-133081358.html|title=General Strike Shuts Down Port of Oakland|publisher=NBC|date=Nov 2, 2011 |accessdate=November 3, 2011}}</ref> A man was arrested for sexual assault and rape at the NYC OWS encampment.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://blogs.wsj.com/metropolis/2011/11/02/man-arrested-in-sex-assaults-at-occupy-wall-street/ | work=The Wall Street Journal | title=Man Arrested in Sex Assaults at Occupy Wall Street | date=November 2, 2011}}</ref>
* '''November 3 (day 48)''' – Firing tear gas and [[flash bang grenades]], riot police clashed with [[Occupy Oakland]] protesters who had built a massive bonfire in the street and refused to leave.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://latimesblogs.latimes.com/lanow/2011/11/occupy-oakland-tear-gas-arrests.html|publisher=LA Times|title=Riot police fire projectiles, arrest dozens of Occupy Oakland protester|date=November 3, 2011|accessdate=November 3, 2011}}</ref> Over a hundred protesters were arrested, including an Iraq veteran who was seriously injured.<ref>[http://abclocal.go.com/kgo/story?section=news/local/east_bay&id=8419771 Second veteran injured in 'Occupy Oakland' violence]</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://news.yahoo.com/occupy-oakland-protesters-tear-gased-police-101824932.html|title=Occupy Oakland Protesters Tear Gassed by Police|publisher=Yahoo News|date=November 3, 2011|accessdate=November 3, 2011}}</ref>
* '''November 5 (day 50)''' – To participate in both [[Guy Fawkes Day]] and [[Bank Transfer Day]], demonstrators protested outside major banks and financial institutions. In the preceding month, over 600,000 people closed their bank accounts and opened accounts with local credit unions. <ref>{{cite web|url=http://inagist.com/OccupyLSX/132973217341120513/|title=600,000 Americans have moved their funds from banks to credit unions in the past month. The revolution is underway.|accessdate=7 November 2011}}</ref>
* '''November 13 (day 58)''' – Occupy Portland camp is, first, defended by the people of the City of Portland, and then cleared by Portland Police Bureau, with the assistance of local, state, and international police forces. A tense stand-off began at midnight and lasted until dawn, with the People forcing the retreat of the Police, until, exhausted and confused, the People were finally pushed out of their encampment when, early on Sunday morning, the Police made an unexpected raid on the camp, violently forcing out the remaining Occupants. The clearing of the camp included multiple arrests, mostly involving campers sitting and Police arresting them without incident. Multiple campers, who were not arrested, were injured at the hands of Police. The clearing of the camp was followed by another standoff at the intersection of SW Main and 4th Avenue. The final stand-off of the day came to an end as the Police made another assault on the people, and on the Constitution, by forcing the move of a General Assembly taking place in the street. Few arrests were made, as only two protestors made symbolic stands against the unConstitutional assault by the Police. The Assembly, in the moments before the Police "cleared the street", made a decision to move their body to Pioneer Square and continue their discussion there. <ref>{{cite web|url=http://wweek.com/portland/article-18220-chaos_to_checkmate.html/|title=chaos to checkmate.|accessdate=1 December 2011}}</ref>
* '''November 14 (day 59)''' – Occupy Oakland is cleared by police; twenty protestors are arrested. Oakland Mayor Jean Quan cited the eviction as a response to the "tremendous strain" the camp had put the city's resources <ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/world/blog/2011/nov/14/occupy-oakland-police-action-live|title=Occupy Oakland: demonstrators prepare for police action â live updates.|accessdate=14 November 2011 | location=London|work=The Guardian|first=Adam|last=Gabbatt|date=November 14, 2011}}</ref> . The mayor's legal advisor, Dan Siegel, has resigned from his position in protest of the eviction. <ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/world/blog/2011/nov/14/occupy-oakland-police-action-live|title=Occupy Oakland: demonstrators prepare for police action â live updates.|accessdate=14 November 2011 | location=London|work=The Guardian|first=Adam|last=Gabbatt|date=November 14, 2011}}</ref>
* '''November 15 (day 60)''' – ** '''Occupy Wall Street''' At about 1am, NYPD began to clear Zuccotti Park. City Councilman Ydanis Rodriguez is reported to have been arrested during the eviction, along with seventy other protestors<ref>{{cite news | url=http://www.nytimes.com/2011/11/16/nyregion/police-begin-clearing-zuccotti-park-of-protesters.html?hp | title=Police Begin Clearing Zuccotti Park of Protester | work=The New York Times | date=November 14, 2011 | accessdate=November 14, 2011 | first1=James | last1=Barron | first2=Colin | last2=Moynihan}}</ref>. The official statement released by Mayor Bloomberg's office explained the purpose of the late-night eviction: "This action was taken at this time of day to reduce the risk of confrontation in the park, and to minimize disruption to the surrounding neighborhood...[Mayor Bloomberg] [has] become increasingly concerned â as had the parkâs owner, Brookfield Properties â that the occupation was coming to pose a health and fire safety hazard to the protestors and to the surrounding community" <ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.nyc.gov/portal/site/nycgov/menuitem.c0935b9a57bb4ef3daf2f1c701c789a0/index.jsp?pageID=mayor_press_release&catID=1194&doc_name=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.nyc.gov%2Fhtml%2Fom%2Fhtml%2F2011b%2Fpr410-11.html&cc=unused1978&rc=1194&ndi=1| title=STATEMENT OF MAYOR MICHAEL R. BLOOMBERG ON CLEARING AND RE-OPENING OF ZUCCOTTI PARK | work=Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg's Office | date=November 15, 2011 | accessdate=November 15, 2011}}</ref>. Journalists have been barred from entering immediate area of eviction since the raid began, and Mayor Bloomberg cited this as a way "to protect members of the press," and "to prevent a situation from getting worse"<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2011/11/15/occupy-wall-street-raid-journalists-arrested_n_1094564.html?ncid=edlinkusaolp00000003| title=Occupy Wall Street 'Media Blackout': Journalists Arrested, Roughed Up, Blocked From Covering Clearing | work=Huffington Post | date=November 15, 2011 | accessdate=November 15, 2011}}</ref>. A CBS press helicopter was not allowed into the airspace above the park, which has been interpreted as an effort to limit media coverage of the event<ref>{{cite news | url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/news/blog/2011/nov/15/occupy-wall-street-police-action-live| title=Occupy Wall Street: police evict protesters - live updates | work=The Guardian| date=November 15, 2011 | accessdate=November 15, 2011 | location=London | first1=Peter | last1=Walker | first2=Matt | last2=Wells}}</ref>. A judge has issued a temporary restraining order in favor of the protestors, requiring Mayor Bloomberg to show cause for eviction <ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.documentcloud.org/documents/266582-order-re-liberty-park/| title=Order to Show Cause and Temporary Restraining Order | work=Restraining Order | date=November 15, 2011 | accessdate=November 15, 2011}}</ref>. Protesters sporting copies of the court order attempted to reenter the park, but police continued to deny access to square. In response, impromptu general assemblies and meet-ups have started in different locations. Mayor Bloomberg is scheduled to address the court order at 11:30am ET<ref>{{cite news | url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/news/blog/2011/nov/15/occupy-wall-street-police-action-live| title=Occupy Wall Street: police evict protesters - live updates | work=The Guardian| date=November 15, 2011 | accessdate=November 15, 2011 | location=London | first1=Peter | last1=Walker | first2=Matt | last2=Wells}}</ref>. Occupy Wall Street's statement released in response to the eviction cited exercising their right to assemble and the need to create a "civic space" as essential to changing public discourse<ref>{{cite web | url=http://occupywallst.org/article/call-occupy/| title=Call to Occupy | work=Occupy Wall Street Official Website| date=November 15, 2011 | accessdate=November 15, 2011}}</ref>. The Mayor's Office released statement states that the right to freedom of speech has not been violated, and furthermore occupying a space with personal property is not included in First Amendment rights; but the Right to Assemble was not addressed in the statement<ref>{{cite news | url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/news/blog/2011/nov/15/occupy-wall-street-police-action-live| title=Occupy Wall Street: police evict protesters - live updates | work=The Guardian| date=November 15, 2011 | accessdate=November 15, 2011 | location=London | first1=Peter | last1=Walker | first2=Matt | last2=Wells}}</ref>. 5,554 books at [[The People's Library]] are confiscated.<ref name='ALA 2011-11-17'> {{cite web | url = http://ala.org/ala/newspresscenter/news/pr.cfm?id=8568 | title = ALA alarmed at seizure of Occupy Wall Street library, loss of irreplaceable material | accessdate = 2011-11-19 | date = 2011-11-17 | archiveurl = http://www.webcitation.org/63J2BDwBW | archivedate = 2011-11-19}}</ref><ref name='Mathias 2011-11-15'> {{cite news | first = Christopher | last = Mathias | title = Occupy Wall Street Library Reportedly Thrown Away By NYPD | date = 2011-11-15 | url = http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2011/11/15/occupy-wall-street-library_n_1094941.html | work = The Huffington Post | accessdate = 2011-11-19|archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/63J6Qf0oS|archivedate=2011-11-19}}</ref> ** '''[[Occupy Cal]]''' gathered over a thousand people at a rally at Sproul Hall plaza. <ref>[http://www.mercurynews.com/top-stories/ci_19339329 Berkeley declares Open University]</ref> ** '''Occupy DC''' staged a sit-in at the DC headquarters of Brookview Properties, which administers New York City's Zuccotti Park. ** '''Occupy UCDavis''' held a rally on the campus which was attended by approximately 2000 people. Later, about 400 individuals occupied the Administration building and held a General Assembly in the space. ** '''[[Occupy Seattle]]''' rallied and marched downtown, police clashed with protestors, used pepper-spray, and arrested six. <ref>[http://seattletimes.nwsource.com/html/localnews/2016775254_apwaoccupyseattle.html Seattle Times: Occupy Seattle marches, blocks streets downtown]</ref><ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.seattlepi.com/local/gallery/Occupy-Seattle-Protests-11-15-11-32102/photo-1758708.php | title=Photos - Occupy Seattle Protests | work=SeattlePI| date=November 15, 2011 | accessdate=November 16, 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite web | url=http://spdblotter.seattle.gov/2011/11/15/demonstration-downtown-six-arrested/ | title=Demonstration downtown, six arrested | work=SPD Blotter, Seattle.gov | date=November 15, 2011 | accessdate=November 16, 2011}}</ref>.
* '''November 16 (day 61)''' – Arrests took place in Portland, Berkeley, San Francisco (95 protestors arrested that night), St Louis and Los Angeles.
* '''November 17 (Day 62)''' – ** '''Occupy Wall Street''' saw crowds of more than 30,000 marching in the streets of New York City. Crowds assembled in and around [[Zuccotti Park]], [[Union Square]], [[Foley Square]], the [[Brooklyn Bridge]], and other locations through the city. <ref>[http://rt.com/usa/news/occupy-wall-street-619/ OWS Day of Action]</ref> ** '''[[Occupy Boston]]''' - Judge issues a restraining order preventing police from evicting protestors. <ref>Nov 17-[http://www.ibtimes.com/articles/251547/20111117/occupy-boston-protesters-win-restraining-order-city.htm Occupy Boston Protestors Win Restraining Order]</ref> ** '''[[Occupy Cal]]''' - Students at UC Berkeley maintained their re-established encampment. ** '''[[Occupy Dallas]]''' - Camp evicted, 18 arrests. <ref>[http://www.chron.com/news/article/Police-evict-all-Occupy-Dallas-protesters-2273812.php Police evict all Occupy Dallas protestors]</ref> ** '''[[Occupy Davis]]''' and '''[[Occupy UC Davis]]''' - Students continued their occupation of the administration building and protestors erected tents on the campus quad. ** '''[[Occupy Los Angeles]]''' - at least 30 were arrested. Protestors occupied Bank of America plaza. <ref>{{cite news| url=http://latimesblogs.latimes.com/lanow/2011/11/orchestrated-arrests-in-downtown-la-protest-police-say.html | work=Los Angeles Times | title=L.A. Now}}</ref> ** '''[[Occupy Milwaukee]]''' - Occupy protestors shut down the North Avenue bridge.<ref>[http://www.jsonline.com/news/milwaukee/occupy-demonstration-closes-north-ave-bridge-es33oum-134083488.html Occupy Demonstration closes North Ave Bridge]</ref> ** '''[[Occupy Portland]]''' - Police in Portland used pepper spray on protestors there. At least 25 arrested on the [[Steel Bridge]]. ** '''[[Occupy Seattle]]''' Occupy protestors marched on University Bridge, blocked traffic. <ref>[http://www.seattlepi.com/local/article/Occupy-protest-marches-on-bridge-blocks-traffic-2274874.php Occupy Protestors Mark on Bridge, Block traffic]</ref> ** '''[[Occupy Spokane]]''' - permit issued permitting protestors to camp. <ref>[http://www.inlander.com/spokane/blog-4523-occupy-spokane-permitted-for-park-occupation.html Permit issued for Park Occupation]</ref> ** '''[[Occupy St. Louis]]''' - Approximately 1,000 marched from the Kiener Plaza occupy site to [[Martin Luther King Bridge (St. Louis)|Martin Luther King Bridge]], where 14 were arrested for blocking an onramp, and later in the afternoon a group temporarily occupies the old Municipal Courts Building adjacent to city hall and unveils large banners proclaiming "Occupy Everything".<ref>{{cite news |last = Fowler |first = Nancy |title = Labor, progressive groups join Occupy StL protesters in push for jobs |newspaper = St. Louis Beacon |location = St. Louis, MO |date = November 17, 2011 |url = http://www.stlbeacon.org/issues-politics/112-region/114286-occupy-stl-protesters-joined-by-labor-others-to-push-for-jobs |accessdate = 2011-11-21 }}</ref>
* '''November 18 (Day 63)''' – Police stage 2:00 am raid <ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?f=/c/a/2011/11/17/BAC61M0GT7.DTL | work=The San Francisco Chronicle | first=Justin | last=Berton | title=Police clear Occupy Cal encampment in predawn raid | date=November 18, 2011}}</ref> at [[Occupy Cal]]. Campus police raid the [[OccupyDavis]] encampment in the morning, pepper-spraying multiple students with no provocation [http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2011/11/19/uc-davis-police-pepper-spray-students_n_1102728.html] :[[Cornell West]], speaking on the closure of the NYC OWS, said, "To think that New York City spent all of that taxpayer money on policing the protesters and arresting people, while right there on Wall Street are all these financial criminals and no one has been charged...The hypocrisy is just too much to take.â [http://www.nytimes.com/2011/11/19/business/occupy-wall-street-has-plenty-of-potential.html?ref=jamesbstewart]
* '''November 19 (Day 64)''' – Former Philadelphian Police Captain Ray Lewis was arrested at Zuccotti park.<ref>[http://www.observer.com/2011/11/former-captain-ray-lewis-charged-with-three-violations-more-photos-of-his-arrest/]</ref> Protesters at the University of California, Davis, were pepper sprayed, prompting outrage.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/northamerica/usa/8902294/Chilling-footage-of-protesters-at-the-University-of-California-being-pepper-sprayed-prompts-outrage.html | location=London | work=The Daily Telegraph | first=Josie | last=Ensor | title='Chilling' footage of protesters at UC Davis being pepper sprayed prompts outrage | date=November 20, 2011}}</ref> [[Newt Gingrich]], former [[Speaker of the United States House of Representatives|Speaker of the House]], suggests OWS protesters "''Go Get a Job Right after You Take a Bath''."<ref>[http://www.weeklystandard.com/blogs/gingrich-occupy-wall-street-go-get-job-right-after-you-take-bath_609253.html]</ref>
* '''November 23 (Day 68)''' – While giving a speech in New Hampshire, President Obama was interrupted by "The Peoples Mic" by Occupy Wall Street protesters. They said, "Mr. President, Over four thousand peaceful protesters have been arrested." before the crowd started chanting "Obama!" over them. Afterwards, a protester handed the president a small piece of paper which read "Mr. President: Over 4000 peaceful protesters have been arrested. While bankers continue to destroy the American economy. You must stop the assault on our 1st amendment rights. Your silence sends a message that police brutality is acceptable. Banks got bailed out. We got sold out." [http://news.yahoo.com/blogs/ticket/occupy-protestor-hands-president-obama-note-201229558.html]
* '''November 30 (Day 75)''' – Police enter the Occupy Los Angeles encampment at City Hall and arrest protesters defying an eviction notice.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://news.yahoo.com/la-police-move-occupy-camp-082656631.html|title=LA police move in on Occupy camp|author=Christina Hoag and Shaya Tayefe Mohajer|publisher=Associated Press|date=November 30, 2011|accessdate=November 30,2011}}</ref>
